persona.name: Mark Weber

occupation.title: Carpenter / Lead Carpenter (Construction worker)
occupation.description: Works on residential and light-commercial projects as a lead carpenter. Responsibilities include reading and interpreting job plans and blueprints, framing, installing windows and doors, building custom cabinetry and trim, coordinating a small crew of 3-5 workers, ensuring on-site safety, ordering materials with the project manager, and troubleshooting issues that arise during builds. Frequently operates power saws, nail guns, and occasionally small excavators. Keeps job logs and communicates with clients on progress. Has OSHA 10-hour training, forklift awareness, and is competent with layout, measuring, and basic structural math. Typical day involves early site arrival, laying out work, directing crew tasks, quality checks, and sometimes weekend overtime during roof or weather-critical phases. Skillset emphasizes practical problem-solving, hands-on making, and on-the-job mentorship for apprentices.

persona.residence: Columbus, Ohio (suburban neighborhood, within city transit options)
persona.education: High school graduate (Central High School, Columbus). Completed a two-week carpentry certificate course at a local vocational/trade school and several employer-sponsored safety and equipment certifications. No college degree.
long_term_goals: Be financially secure enough to slow down physically at 60 and manage chronic joint pain without worry.
Own a small workshop where he can take on custom carpentry projects and restore older houses around the neighborhood.
Maintain a strong marriage and travel with his wife a couple of times a year to national parks and regional board game conventions.
Be a known, reliable face in the local volunteer network — help run youth build days and neighborhood improvements.
Have a comfortable retirement (modest home paid off, 401(k) contributions maintained) and leave a small legacy for his siblings.
Master a handful of complicated strategy board games and host annual multi-table game nights that friends look forward to.
Learn to manage impulse spending so savings and emergency fund reach six months of expenses.
Improve his physical conditioning to reduce back pain and avoid future injuries.
Be respected as a team lead at work and possibly move into a supervisory foreman role.
Be seen as dependable by his community — someone people call when they need help moving, fixing, or building.
persona.style: Direct, friendly, midwestern conversational style with a practical earthy tone. Speech: steady, slightly gravelly from years of outdoor work, uses plain-language, colloquialisms like "y'know," "gimme a sec," and occasional colorful metaphors. Accent: Midwestern (Columbus-area) — non-rhotic tendencies minimal, relaxed vowels. Mannerisms: firm handshake, habit of rubbing knuckles when thinking, often stands with hands on hips, loosens up with a wide chuckle when comfortable. Dress: heavy-duty work boots (worn Red Wing), straight-leg jeans, Carhartt or flannel shirts, baseball cap with local hardware store logo. Grooming: short hair, trimmed beard with touch of gray at the chin, visible faded tattoo of a compass on forearm from early twenties. Digital demeanor: quick to text, uses short messages and emojis sparingly (thumbs-up), posts photos of finished projects and board-game nights on a private Facebook group. Social tone: polite and cooperative, avoids public conflict, seeks compromise. Communication preferences: prefers phone calls for urgent matters and face-to-face conversations for important topics. When stressed, he speaks more loudly and more quickly, tapping surfaces to emphasize points.

traits: High sensation-seeking: enjoys hands-on risk and novelty (motorcycle rides, trying new game mechanics, adventurous weekend hikes).
Impulsive in small ways: will buy a new power tool on a whim or impulse-buy a limited-run board game.
Agreeable and cooperative: dependable teammate on job sites, community-minded, volunteers time for neighborhood build days.
Conflict-avoidant: works to smooth tensions, will back down in heated arguments to preserve relationships.
Pragmatic problem-solver: focuses on practical solutions rather than theory.
Loyal and steady: once committed to friends or employers, tends to stick it out through tough times.
Sociable in small groups: prefers close friends and game nights to large, loud parties.
Moderate pride in workmanship: sensitive to criticism about quality of work.
Humorous with dry sarcasm: light teasing that signals closeness.
Occasional impatience: frustrated by bureaucracy or slow decision-making.
Curious about mechanics: enjoys disassembling and fixing small engines or furniture.
Community-minded volunteer: helps local school fundraisers and charity builds.
Emotionally reserved: shares feelings selectively, often through actions rather than words.

big_five.openness: Medium-Low (around 35/100). Practical and concrete in outlook, but open to new experiential activities like novel board games or weekend adventures.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium-High (around 70/100). Reliable, punctual on job sites, takes pride in quality; can be messy outside of work.
big_five.extraversion: Medium (around 55/100). Energized by small-group socializing (work crew, game night), not by large crowds.
big_five.agreeableness: High (around 80/100). Cooperative, trusting, community-oriented, avoids conflict.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium (around 45/100). Generally even-keeled but feels stress under financial strain or chronic pain; may ruminate briefly.

interests: Board games (primary interest) — collects and plays weekly with a 6-person regular group.
Motorcycling (weekend afternoon rides on secondary roads).
Weekend DIY projects: small cabinets, benches, porch repairs.
Local community volunteer builds (Habitat for Humanity style events).
Tailgate grilling / backyard barbecues with friends.
Fishing on nearby lakes occasionally (relaxation and social time).
Competitively watching college football (Ohio State fan but not rabid).
Podcasts about woodworking, tool maintenance, and board-game strategy.
Occasional craft beer tastings; favors local microbreweries.
Car and truck maintenance — prefers hands-on learning.
likes: Board game specifics: Eurogames with engine-building (Wingspan, Terraforming Mars variants), light-to-medium Ameritrash (Scythe, Root), worker-placement mechanics, heavy thematic legacy games on occasion.

Favorite board games: Ticket to Ride (for quick friends nights), Caverna (for deep solo-style puzzle sessions), Root (for asymmetric strategy), Splendor (fast filler), Pandemic Legacy (cooperative storytelling experience).
Expansions: Collects key expansions rather than every one; prioritizes ones that improve replayability or add new factions.
Local board game store: 'City Meeples' — likes its staff, the events board, and draft nights.
Game-night snacks: stovetop popcorn with Old Bay, pulled pork sliders, IPA beers, coffee for late sessions.
Game-night ambiance: bright table lamp, felt table topper, organized cups for tokens, spare sleeves for cards, a Bluetooth speaker playing classic rock quietly.
Tools: favorite circular saw (brand-specific), set of chisels, cordless impact driver, 18V battery platform.
Clothing: comfortable work clothes, flannel shirts, sturdy boots.
Vehicles: dependable pickup truck (10-year-old Ford F-150) with a toolbox in the bed.
Food: country-style ribs, grilled vegetables, diner breakfasts on Sundays.
Entertainment: likes practical how-to YouTube channels (woodworking, car repair) and board-game review channels (The Dice Tower, Rahdo Runs Through).
Books: woodworking manuals, one or two memoirs by tradespeople, tactical baseball history books.
Gadgets: likes practical gadgets—digital calipers, Bluetooth headlamps for night projects.
Holidays: family-centered holidays, hosts Friendsgiving and Memorial Day cookouts.
Vacation style: road trips and national parks rather than expensive overseas travel.
Shopping habits: prefers to inspect tools in-store; will research expensive purchases online.
Music: classic rock, heartland rock, some modern country for riding out on the highway.
Social: prefers recurring commitments (weekly game night) over spontaneous large parties.
Learning: favors hands-on apprenticeships and master-apprentice learning over formal coursework.
Home: likes a workshop corner in the garage with pegboard organization.
dislikes: Games with excessive tabled bookkeeping or long, poorly balanced luck elements.
Pretentiousness in hobby communities and gatekeeping around board games.
Micromanagement on job sites and bureaucratic red tape.
Expensive specialty tools sold as 'must-haves' when a cheaper solution works fine.
Crowded city-center events with long lines (prefers suburban parks).
Cold, wet winters that delay exterior work.
High-interest debt and predatory lending practices.
Restaurants that take a long time to seat groups or rush diners to leave.
Online-only interactions for important decisions; prefers face-to-face.
Being pigeonholed as 'just a tradesman' — dislikes people downplaying the craft.
board_games_detail: Hosts a weekly Wednesday night game group of 4-6 regulars who rotate hosting duties.
Organizes an annual spring 'game-a-thon' at his garage with 3 separate tables and potluck food.
Owns approximately 60-80 games, curated with a mix of gateway, medium, and heavy strategy titles.
Keeps a digital spreadsheet tracking ownership, expansions, play counts, and who enjoyed what.
Sleeves nearly all card-heavy games, prefers matte sleeves for shuffling and durability.
Favorite mechanics: area control, engine building, asymmetric factions, and worker placement.
Dislikes long rules explanations; favors concise, well-drafted rulebooks and short tutorial videos.
Will teach new players using a demo game or play a 'practice round' without competitive scoring.
Enjoys introducing novices with Ticket to Ride or Splendor before progressing to heavier titles.
Occasionally attends local game store tournaments and demo days to try new games.
Listens to board-game podcasts while driving to work to learn strategy ideas.
Plays solo variants when friends are unavailable (Terraforming Mars solo mode is a comfort pick).
Has a collection of foam trays and organizers to speed setup and teardown.
Respects gaming etiquette: not phone-checking during games, helps less-experienced players, and keeps jokes good-natured.
Buys limited-run Kickstarter games sparingly; prefers ones with strong community feedback.
Trades games occasionally with friends, often swapping duplicates for others he wants.
Collects artwork and special editions if they materially enhance gameplay or replayability.
Appreciates cooperative games for family-like teamwork experiences but values competitive play for strategy nights.
Enjoys legacy campaigns for a shared narrative experience, but prefers revocable or resettable campaigns for regular groups.
Keeps a small shelf in the living room for 'current rotation' games that stay easily accessible.

beliefs: Work ethic: honest, steady labor is honorable and shapes character.
Education: vocational training and apprenticeships are valuable and underappreciated compared with four-year degrees.
Politics: leans Republican on fiscal issues, favors lower taxes and support for small business, but pragmatic rather than doctrinaire.
Gun policy: supports closing the gun-show loophole and background checks for offsite sales, while preserving lawful hunting and self-defense rights.
Community: local governments should support volunteerism and practical neighborhood improvements.
Unionization: supportive of unions in principle for fair wages and safety but wary of corrupt leadership or strikes that threaten community projects.
Healthcare: basic access to affordable care is important; supports practical reforms to reduce surprise medical bills.
Immigration: favors sensible, controlled immigration that enforces the law while recognizing labor needs in construction and trades.
Law and order: respects police and first responders; supports accountability but dislikes reflexive defunding rhetoric.
Environment: believes in stewarding local land (parks, waterways) and supports common-sense measures to reduce pollution; skeptical of large, expensive federal mandates that hurt local economies.
Climate: acknowledges human influence on climate but prefers market-based or incremental solutions that don't cripple local jobs.
Social values: family stability is important; marriage is respected as a partnership and practical support system.
Fiscal policy: concerned about federal deficits and prefers balanced budgets; supports prudent local government spending.
Small business: local hardware stores and tradespeople should be protected from unfair competition with large corporate chains.
Technology: values practical tech that saves time and improves safety on the job but resists novelty for its own sake.
Education policy: more funding for trade schools, apprenticeships, and skilled training programs.
Role of government: government should provide basic safety nets but not micromanage every aspect of life.
Charity: prefers private, local-charity responses and volunteerism over distant federal programs when possible.
Religion and morality: culturally Christian background, attends church on major holidays and for community events, but is not extremely doctrinaire.
Family planning: supports people's choices about having children; personally content to have none, viewing it as his and his wife's decision.
Voting: believes in civic duty — votes in local and national elections and leans Republican but will split-ticket if a candidate is competent.
Media: distrustful of national news outlets for perceived bias; trusts local news and firsthand accounts more.
Trade respect: tradespeople deserve respect and a living wage; not ashamed of being in construction.
Personal freedom: individual responsibility is important; people should be accountable for debts and decisions, but compassion helps when misfortune hits.
Criminal justice: favors rehabilitation programs tied to job training for non-violent offenders.
Gun ownership: believes in safe storage, firearm education, and background checks for private sale; opposes rhetoric that paints all gun owners as extremists.
Neighborhood policing: supports community policing models that build relationships rather than confrontation.
Public spending: approves of infrastructure spending that improves roads and bridges; skeptical of projects without clear local benefit.
Corporate regulation: tolerates necessary regulation for safety and fairness but dislikes unnecessary red tape that slows small contractors.
Foreign policy: prefers non-interventionist posture unless core national interests or allies are directly threatened.
Mental health: believes mental health resources should be more accessible; stigma prevents men from seeking help.
Emergencies: supports emergency savings and basic household preparedness (generator, first-aid kit).
Personal privacy: wary of big-tech data collection and supports reasonable privacy protections.
Voting rights: supports reasonable measures to ensure the integrity of elections without unduly burdening voters.
Educational content: thinks schools should teach practical life skills (budgeting, carpentry basics) alongside academics.
Workplace safety: strict safety standards are necessary; employers should be accountable for worker safety.
Child welfare: believes children deserve stable homes and that communities should support at-risk families.
Local investment: endorses municipal investments in parks, public schools, and community centers which make neighborhoods livable.
skills: Framing, trim work, and finish carpentry (door/window installation, cabinetry).
Reading blueprints and basic construction math (angles, material estimation).
Operate common job-site power tools (miter saw, circular saw, table saw, nail guns) safely and efficiently.
Small equipment operation: experience with skid-steer and small excavators (basic competence).
Project coordination: scheduling subtrades, ordering materials, and sequencing tasks for a small crew.
On-the-job mentorship: training apprentices in safe tool use and basic carpentry techniques.
Basic plumbing and electrical patching knowledge for finishing work (not licensed).
Problem diagnosis: quickly identifying structural or finishing issues and proposing practical fixes.
Shop skills: sanding, applying finishes, gluing, clamping, and creating jigs for repeatable work.
Tool maintenance: sharpening blades, diagnosing battery issues, basic small-engine maintenance.
Budget-aware procurement: cost-conscious ordering, negotiating with suppliers for best pricing.
Basic first aid and CPR (community class certification).
Automotive maintenance: changing brakes, oil, and basic troubleshooting on his pickup.
Board-game mastery: teaching rules, facilitating games, understanding meta-strategy in popular titles.
People management: calming disputes among crew members, delegating tasks, and ensuring productivity.
Time management: efficient day planning to hit deadlines and manage weather-related delays.
Sales and client relations: explaining change orders, presenting reasonable timelines, and managing client expectations.
Problem-solving under pressure: adapting to unexpected site conditions (rot, water, shifting grades).
Home repair skills: drywall patching, basic roof repair, deck maintenance.
Basic budgeting and personal finance skills: tracks expenses, contributes to 401(k), manages mortgage payments.

general: Punctual: arrives early to job sites to set up and brief crew.
Hands-on leader: prefers to work alongside crew rather than staying in the office.
Polite and helpful to neighbors; often asked to lend tools or advice.
Avoids prolonged online debates; will politely exit podcasts or comment sections that get toxic.
Likes to unwind with a couple of beers and a game rather than a night at a loud bar.
Impulsive purchases: occasionally buys a limited-run board game or new tool without long deliberation.
Keeps a small notebook in his truck for measurements, quick sketches, and to-do lists.
Prefers analog planning: printed checklists for job tasks and a paper calendar for personal events.
Uses humor and teasing to ease tension at work; avoids heavy emotional conversations in public.
Tends to fix things himself before calling a professional, even when paying for time off would be easier.

morning: Wakes at 5:30 AM on workdays, shower, black coffee, eggs or diner-style breakfast twice a week.
Checks weather and job messages while drinking coffee, then loads tools into the truck.
Arrives at site by 7:00 AM, does a quick safety huddle with crew, lays out the day's plan.
Listens to a woodworking or blue-collar podcast during the drive occasionally.
workday: Works hard physically for 8-10 hours with breaks for lunch; coordinates with suppliers by phone.
Handles measurement and layout tasks in the morning, precision finish work in the afternoon.
Records progress and some photos for the project manager's log.
If schedule allows, calls his wife around mid-afternoon to check in and coordinate dinner plans.
evening: Arrives home around 5:30–6:30 PM depending on project.
Helps with household chores (lawn mowing, minor repairs) and prepares or grills dinner with his wife a few nights per week.
Hosts or attends weekly game night on Wednesday; sometimes invites newer friends to learn a game.
Spends 30–60 minutes in the garage shop on personal projects several nights per week.
Before bed, checks the calendar for the next day's work and responds to essential messages.
weekend: Saturday mornings: ride the motorcycle with a friend or run errands and hit the local hardware store early.
Saturday afternoons: volunteer at a community build or take on a side gig repair for a friend.
Sunday: family-oriented — church on major holidays or community events, long brunch, and board-game afternoon or evening.
Occasional weekend trips to regional game conventions or a lake fishing day with close friends once every few months.

physical.general: Overall fairly healthy and physically active due to manual labor; muscular build with some wear-and-tear.
physical.chronic_conditions: Mild lower-back pain and occasional shoulder stiffness from repetitive lifting; early osteoarthritis in right knee suspected by a previous physician but not disabling.
physical.recent_issues: Sustained a sprained wrist three years ago from a fall on a job; recovered but cautious about ladders.
physical.fitness: Keeps active through work and weekend rides; does informal stretching routine but no formal gym schedule.
physical.diet: Omnivore diet with preference for grilled meats and home-cooked meals; tries to include vegetables but admits to fast-food lunches on busy days.
physical.substance_use: Social drinker (1-3 beers multiple times a week); quit daily smoking in late twenties after a brief period of occasional cigarettes; does not use recreational hard drugs.
physical.vision_hearing: Needs reading glasses for close-up work occasionally; hearing slightly diminished in right ear after years of tool noise — uses ear protection regularly now.
physical.vaccinations: Up to date on common adult vaccines; received flu shot annually.
physical.sleep: 7 hours typical on worknights; sometimes interrupted by pain or thinking about finances.
physical.preventive_care: Gets physicals every 2-3 years and dental cleanings annually; would go more often if schedule allowed.
physical.mental_health: Generally stable mood but experiences occasional stress and worry tied to finances and job stability; values stoicism but has warmed to the idea of counseling for stress management.
physical.medications: Occasional NSAIDs for pain; uses topical analgesics on sore days; no chronic prescriptions.
physical.allergies: Seasonal pollen allergies; over-the-counter antihistamines when needed.

relationships.name: Emily Weber
relationships.description: Married for 9 years. Emily works part-time as a dental assistant and handles much of the household organization. Their relationship is warm, practical, and affectionate. They share game nights, home projects, and cooking duties. They decided together not to have children; both are content with that choice. Emily is Mark's closest confidante and often helps mediate his impulsive purchases.

Retired factory worker (dad) and school cafeteria worker (mom) living in a neighboring suburb. Close relationship; visit weekly for Sunday supper. Dad taught Mark basic woodworking and safety lessons in his teens.

relationships.name: Younger sister: Rachel Weber
relationships.description: Lives about 40 minutes away. Works in retail management. Close, supportive relationship; they swap favors and help with her occasional home repairs.
A small circle of co-workers and two regular apprentices. Considered friends; they carpool occasionally and socialize after work with beers and quick catch-ups.

Core group of 4-6 friends from varied backgrounds (teacher, software tester, electrician). They rotate hosting duties and are social anchors for Mark — he mentors some new players, teaches rules, and organizes potlucks.
Friendly relationship with immediate neighbors; helps with yardwork and small repairs, swaps garden produce in season. Known locally as someone reliable for odd jobs.

relationships.name: Eric
relationships.description: Longtime friend from high school, rides motorcycles together, confidant for personal issues; they talk once a week.
Volunteer coordinator at the city community center and a contractor contact at the local supplier who offers trade discounts and flexible billing terms.

other_facts: Grew up in a blue-collar family in a Midwestern suburb; father was a factory foreman and mother worked in school services.
Learned basic carpentry from his father at age 13, building treehouses and repairing family furniture.
Dropped out of any college plans after high school to start earning and enter the trades; took pride in starting a meaningful career early.
Met his wife Emily at a community summer festival where she was working a food booth; shared a mutual love of board games after discovering a common friend group.
Married at age 33 in a small backyard ceremony with close family and friends; no children by mutual decision.
Had an early job as a general laborer for a local builder and worked nights attending short trade classes to improve skills.
Was nearly seriously injured in a job-site fall when he was 28; recovered and became more cautious about ladders and harnessing.
Has a dependable 2012 Ford F-150 with 150k miles; keeps it running himself and takes pride in maintaining it.
Owns a small workshop corner in his two-car garage with a bench, router table, and tool chest; loves the smell of planed wood.
Keeps a small emergency fund in a separate savings account (about 3 months of expenses) and contributes regularly to a 401(k) through his employer.
Volunteer history includes two seasons with Habitat-style home builds and organizing a neighborhood park cleanup day.
Once ran a weekend side gig fixing neighbors' decks and porches; it helped bridge a vacation shortfall one summer.
Has a faded compass tattoo on his right forearm from his early twenties, symbolizing direction and home.
Attended a local community safety class and is on the list of volunteers for neighborhood emergency response drills.
Regularly donates broken or surplus tools to a local apprenticeship program for teens interested in trades.
A notable early memory: building a model airplane with his father and winning a small county fair prize; this cemented his love for making things.
Loves old vinyl records and has a small collection of classic-rock albums he plays in the garage while working on hobby projects.
Once took Emily on a spontaneous weekend to Cuyahoga Valley National Park after a particularly stressful month at work — a turning point for prioritizing time off.
Has been ticketed once for a moving violation while rushing between jobs and has since adopted a more deliberate driving style.
Participated in a local political door-knock for a municipal candidate he respected, though he rarely engages in partisan campaigning.
Keeps a running list of tools he'd like to acquire; Emily sometimes hides the list when finances are tight to curb impulsive buys.
Practices simple financial discipline: automatic contributions to savings and retirement and a weekly budget review with Emily.
Enjoys teaching his nephew basic woodworking skills during holiday visits.
Has a ritual of cleaning and oiling favorite tools every Sunday evening to keep them in top condition.
Values small traditions: a Friday night 'fish fry' when the crew finishes a tough week, and a mid-winter chili cook-off with neighbors.
Has a 'first job' photo in his living room: 17-year-old Mark in a hardhat, proud and wide-eyed.
Feels guilt about not being more vocal on emotional topics and is actively trying to be more expressive in his marriage.
Once assembled a complex custom gaming table for a friend's donation raffle; it raised significant funds for a school fundraiser.
Has an album of photos documenting major projects and game nights, a favored memory tool for holidays and anniversaries.
Occasionally loses patience with slow-moving administrative processes at work, then decompresses by going for a long motorcycle ride.
Keeps a small box of mementos (tickets, postcards, small tools) that remind him of personal milestones and family events.
Has a vivid childhood memory of a neighbor teaching him to fish — a formative bonding moment and introduction to patient, quiet activity.
Is mildly superstitious about bringing a small brass charm in his pocket on important job starts (a wedding gift from his grandfather).
In his early thirties, briefly tried freelance remodeling alone and realized he prefers stable employment with predictable paychecks.
Has been approached to mentor a high-school-age apprentice through a city workforce program and has agreed to meet monthly.
Saves the first paycheck of each year into a 'fun fund' used for a weekend trip or a larger-than-usual hobby purchase.
Has a practical 'rule of three' when evaluating purchases: need, frequency of use, and long-term value; Emily reminds him of those rules.

Remembers a harrowing moment when a client once threatened legal action over a misunderstanding; handled it by documenting communications and smoothing the relationship, which strengthened his professional practices.
Loves the tactile feel of good wood and often picks up offcuts to imagine future projects; the scent triggers fond, calming memories.
Has a small planted vegetable garden behind the garage; enjoys the slow, visible rewards of tending it and sharing produce with neighbors.
Was once invited to judge a local high-school carpentry competition and found the experience unexpectedly rewarding and inspiring.
Keeps a small stash of emergency tools and a printed list of local trade contacts in the glovebox for surprise repairs or client needs.
Believes in a practical legacy: teaching skills to younger generations rather than leaving a large monetary inheritance.
